heading.title: PART 21 DISCOVERY, INSPECTION AND NOTICE TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTS [rr 21.1–21.13]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 21 DISCOVERY, INSPECTION AND NOTICE TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTS [rr 21.1–21.13]

leg:heading.title: DISCOVERY, INSPECTION AND NOTICE TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTS [rr 21.1–21.13]

row.entry: This rule specifies relevance to facts in issue as the criterion of discoverability in compliance with an order under UCPR r 21.2 . It excludes from discovery various documents, including the pleadings in the proceedings, documents created or served since the commencement of the proceedings, and certain classes of original and copied documents.

These rules permit the court to order discovery of specified classes or examples of documents. They require special reasons to obtain discovery in personal injury proceedings. The rules prescribe the formal contents of lists of discovered documents and their verifying affidavit. They describe the scope of the discovering party’s obligation to produce documents for inspection. Unless wider leave is granted, the rules confine use of discovered documents to use in the proceedings.

entry.emph: Division 2 — Notice to produce before hearing — Rules 21.9–21.13

row.entry: These rules permit parties to issue notices for the production of documents referred to in pleadings, affidavits and witness statements. In non-personal injury cases, the notice can also require the production of other specified documents. The rules oblige the party served with a notice to produce the documents after a reasonable time (usually 14 days) or to specify any privilege claim made in respect of the documents.

This Part does not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division or the DDT or the Industrial Relations Commission (when acting otherwise than as the Industrial Court) (except to the extent to which the Commission orders that the Part is to apply): see UCPR r 1.5 and Sch 1.

The Part is to substantially the same effect as discovery powers located in the former SCR Pt 23 and DCR Pt 22. There were no previous rules in the Local Court which provided for discovery and inspection or notices to produce. There are significant changes where questions of self-incrimination privilege arise and the rules are complemented by CPA s 87 and the definition of privileged information in the Dictionary to the UCPR.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 21.1] r 21.1 Definitions (cf SCR Part 23, rule 1; DCR Part 22, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Definitions (cf SCR Part 23, rule 1; DCR Part 22, rule 1)

p.text: In this Division:
, in relation to proceedings the subject of an order for discovery, means any of the following documents:
any document filed in the proceedings,
any document served on party A after the commencement of the proceedings,
any document that wholly came into existence after the commencement of the proceedings,

any additional copy of a document included in the list of documents, being a document that contains no mark, deletion or other matter, relevant to a fact in question, not present in the document so included,
any document comprising an original written communication sent by party B prior to the date of commencement of the proceedings of which a copy is included in the list of documents,
but does not include any document that the court declares not to be an excluded document for the purposes of those proceedings.
means a list of documents referred to in rule 21.3 .
means an order referred to in rule 21.2 .
means a party to whom another party is giving discovery, or being ordered to give discovery, of documents.
means a party who is giving discovery, or being ordered to give discovery, of documents.
means an affidavit prepared in relation to the list of documents under rule 21.4 .
See the Dictionary for further definitions including, in particular, a definition of possession.

For the purposes of this Division, a document or matter is to be taken to be relevant to a fact in issue if it could, or contains material that could, rationally affect the assessment of the probability of the existence of that fact (otherwise than by relating solely to the credibility of a witness), regardless of whether the document or matter would be admissible in evidence.
Legislation cited in [21.1.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Interpretation Act 1987 s 21.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 Dictionary.

The definition of “document” in the Dictionary to the rules merely includes “parts” and “copies” of documents. However there is a more elaborate and inclusive definition in s 21 of the Interpretation Act 1987 and that definition is reflected in the Dictionary to the Evidence Act 1995 and also in SCR 1.8. The question of what falls within the definition of “document” arises principally in connection with discovery and subpoena issues. A tape recording is a discoverable document: Australian National Airlines Commission v Commonwealth (1975) 132 CLR 582 at 594; 6 ALR 433 ; Grant v Southwestern and County Properties Ltd [1975] Ch 185; [1974] 2 All ER 465 ; Cassidy v Engwirda Constructions Co [1967] QWN 16 ; cf Beneficial Finance Corp Ltd v Conway [1970] VR 321 . A video cassette recording is a discoverable document: Radio 10 Pty Ltd v Brisbane TV Ltd [1984] 1 Qd R 113; (1984) 75 FLR 1 . Information stored in a computer readable form is also discoverable: Alliance and Lester Building Society v Ghahremani [1992] TLR 129 ; Derby & Co Ltd v Weldon (No 9) [1991] 2 All ER 901; [1991] 1 WLR 652 ; Ange v Fairfax Media Publications Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 1200; BC201008537 (emails and other forms of electronic communication included). A mobile phone containing relevant material can be a discoverable “document”: Palavi v Radio 2UE Sydney Pty Ltd [2011] NSWCA 264; BC201106918 (destruction of mobile phones containing relevant material in defiance of known orders for discovery).

The concept of “facts in issue” refers to the nature of the issues and not necessarily to the actual subject matter of the proceedings. Thus, in an action for possession of land where the plaintiff’s title is in dispute, the “facts in issue” relate to the title, and those that merely relate to the land itself are not “in issue”: Phillips v Phillips (1879) 40 LT 815. A fact in issue is a material allegation relating to the substance of the dispute — irrespective of whether or not it is an issue that has been expressly joined on the pleadings: Schlam v WA Trustee Executor and Agency Co Ltd [1964] WAR 178 ; Friedrich v Baxter (1991) 56 SASR 562 ; Martin and Biro Seven Ltd v H Millwood Ltd [1956] 71 RPC 316. But the facts in issue in proceedings will primarily be identified by examination of the pleadings and consideration of any admissions that the parties have made, whether in the pleadings or elsewhere: Mulley v Manifold (1959) 103 CLR 341 at 345; 33 ALJR 168; BC5900640 .

level.toc-caption: [21.1.10] Documents relevant to a fact in issue

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.1.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.1(2).
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 55, 56.

heading.title: Documents relevant to a fact in issue

p.text: Under r 21.1(2) , the relevance of a document to a fact in issue is to be determined by its capacity to “rationally affect the assessment of the probability of the existence” of the contentious fact. If a document has that capacity it will be “relevant” and thus satisfy the threshold requirement of admissibility under ss 55 and 56 of the Evidence Act 1995. But admissibility as such is not a pre-condition to the discoverability of otherwise relevant documents: Compagnie Financiere v Peruvian Guano Co (1882) 52 LJQB 181; 11 QBD 55 at 62 ; O’Rourke v Darbishire [1920] AC 581 at 630; [1920] All ER Rep 1 ; Donaldson v Harris (1973) 4 SASR 299 at 305 ; Ferguson v Mackaness Produce Pty Ltd [1970] 2 NSWR 66 at 68 ; Merchants & Manufacturers Insurance Co Ltd v Davies [1938] 1 KB 196 at 210 . In evaluating the capacity of a document to “rationally affect the assessment of the probability of the existence” of a fact, it is important to bear in mind not only that the document need not be admissible, but also that it does not need to be directly probative of the existence of the fact in question. Accordingly, the discovery test under the present rules is still relatively wide and, in a very general sense, it is still appropriate to say that everything which would “throw light on the case” is prima facie subject to the discovery obligation: Hutchinson v Glover (1875) 1 QBD 138 . In determining the permissible scope of discovery, the court ought have regard to the respective parties' entitlement to rely upon an “evidentiary mosaic” and should not unduly restrict the scope of documents that may be relevant to a fact in issue: Lakatoi Universal Pty Ltd v Walker [1998] NSWSC 470 ; Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [1999] NSWSC 1026; BC9907448 . Particular examples of discoverable documents include:
where the handwriting of another document is in issue — documents that facilitate the comparison of disputed handwriting: Jones v Richards (1885) 15 QBD 439 ;

in a product liability claim — documents evidencing complaints by other users about the safety of the product: Board v Thomas Hedley & Co Ltd [1951] 2 All ER 431 ; Edmiston v British Transport Commission [1956] 1 QB 191; [1955] 3 All ER 823 ;
documents relevant to the amount of damages claimed are discoverable;

where it is alleged that a party is carrying on a particular business — documents relating to business transactions by that party — because they would tend to show the nature of any business being carried on by the defendant: Marshall v Goulston Discount (Northern) Ltd [1967] Ch 72;

in a case where a plaintiff is seeking relief in equity — any material that goes to ensuring the effectiveness and adequacy of the final decree or order unless, perhaps, the issue of damages or other relief has been postponed, and in that case discovery on those issues may also be postponed: National Commercial Bank v Wimborne (NSWSC, Young J, 4 May 1992, unreported, BC9201904); Schreiber v Heymann (1894) 63 LJQB 749 .

Despite the potential width of the “relevance” criterion, the discovery obligation does not extend to a merely speculative possibility or suggestion that a document may contain relevant material: Commonwealth v Northern Land Council (1991) 30 FCR 1; 103 ALR 267 at 290 . The criterion of discovery under the present rules is more restrictive than was the case under previous rules considered in some of the older authorities. In particular, it was formerly said that documents were discoverable if they might “lead to a train of inquiry” that might affect either party’s case: Mulley v Manifold (1959) 103 CLR 341; 33 ALJR 168; BC5900640 ; Compagnie Financiere v Peruvian Guano Co (1882) 52 LJQB 181; 11 QBD 55 at QBD 63 . But under the present rules, documents which only have a “chain of inquiry” value will not be discoverable: National Australia Bank Ltd v Idoport Pty Ltd [2000] NSWCA 8; BC200000274 .

level.toc-caption: [21.1.20] Documents relevant to a party’s own case

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.1.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.1(2).

heading.title: Documents relevant to a party’s own case

p.text: Some formulations of the width of the discovery obligation under earlier rules suggested that it was limited to documents that might reasonably be supposed to contain information that may (not must) either directly or indirectly enable the party requiring discovery to advance its own case, or to damage the case of an opponent: Mulley v Manifold (1959) 103 CLR 341; 33 ALJR 168; BC5900640 ; Compagnie Financiere v Peruvian Guano Co (1882) 52 LJQB 181; 11 QBD 55 at 63 . These formulations leave out of account documents that are detrimental to a party’s own case. Such a narrow view of the discovery obligation is inconsistent with the definition of relevance in r 21.1(2) and also with judicial encouragement for a wide interpretation of the extent of the discovery obligation: Seidler v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1983] 2 NSWLR 390 at 392 . Accordingly, a document is potentially discoverable if it is relevant in the sense set out in r 21.1(2) and irrespective of whether or not the fact to which it is relevant, advances or impedes the discovering party’s own case or that of its opponent.

The occurrence of matters that are similar to the facts in issue in the litigation may sometimes be sufficiently relevant to justify an order for discovery in relation to them: Thorpe v Chief Constable of Greater Manchester Police [1989] 2 All ER 827; [1989] 1 WLR 665 at 669 ; Zaknic Pty Ltd v Svelte Corp Ltd (1995) 61 FCR 171; 140 ALR 701; BC9501966 (previous similar representations to other persons); Mahlo v Westpac Banking Corp (NSWSC, Santow J, 21 November 1996, unreported, BC9606827). Usually this will occur if the other facts are relevant to questions of knowledge or, for example, the objective qualities of mass produced goods: Board v Thomas Hedley & Co Ltd [1951] 2 All ER 431 ; Blakebrough v British Motor Corp Ltd (1969) 113 Sol Jo 366 . Discovery should be refused if the material sought relates merely to matters of common fact that are of no probative relevance in relation to proof of matters in issue in the proceedings: Permanent Finance Corp Ltd v Europacific (Plant Hire) Pty Ltd (No 2) [1971] Qd R 302 ; Thorpe v Chief Constable of Greater Manchester Police [1989] 2 All ER 827; [1989] 1 WLR 665 ; Kennedy v Dodson [1895] 1 Ch 334 .
Legislation cited in [21.1.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.1(2).

The credibility of a witness is not regarded as being relevant to a fact in issue for the purpose of discovery: see r 21.1(2) . Accordingly, discovery solely for the purpose of obtaining documents to impeach the credit of a witness or the opposing party will usually be refused: George Ballantine & Son Ltd v FER Dixon & Son Ltd [1974] 2 All ER 503; [1974] 1 WLR 1125 ; Beecham Group Ltd v Bristol-Meyers Co Ltd [1979] VR 273 at 277–8 ; Kennedy v Dodson [1895] 1 Ch 334 . As to the potential difficulty of characterising matters as going solely to the credit of a particular witness, see [33.4.18] .

level.toc-caption: [21.1.35] Alternative rights to obtain or inspect documents

heading.title: Alternative rights to obtain or inspect documents

p.text: Remedies other than discovery may be available in appropriate cases to obtain the production and inspection of documents. The court may enforce a right to inspect documents by a mandatory order: R v Southwold Corp (1907) 97 LT 431 ; R v Bradford on Avon Rural District Council; Ex parte Thornton (1908) 99 LT 89 ; Davies v Gas Light and Coke Co [1909] 1 Ch 248 at 253 ; R v Godstone Rural District Council [1911] 2 KB 465 ; R v Barnes Borough Council; Ex parte Conlan [1938] 3 All ER 226 . For the right of a shareholder to inspect company documents, see Bank of Bombay v Suleman Somji (1908) 99 LT 62 ; Lemon v Austin Friars Trust Ltd [1926] Ch 1 (debenture holder); Re Australian Marinas (A’asia) Pty Ltd [1975] VR 372 (plaintiff in oppression suit); s 319 of the Corporations Law 1989 (order for inspection by auditor or legal practitioner on members behalf); Re Augold NL (1986) 11 ACLR 362 ; Knightswood Nominees Pty Ltd v Sherwin Pastoral Co Ltd (1989) 15 ACLR 151 at 156; 7 ACLC 536 ; Bride v Commissioner for Corporate Affairs (1989) 1 ACSR 36 ; Re Claremont Petroleum NL (1989) 1 ACSR 494 ; Cescastle Pty Ltd v Renak Holdings Ltd (1991) 6 ACSR 115 ; Humes Ltd v Unity APA Ltd (1987) 11 ACLR 641; Quinlan v Vital Technology Australia Ltd (1987) 5 ACLC 389 ; Intercapital Holdings Ltd v MEH Ltd (1988) 13 ACLR 595 ; Barrack Mines Ltd v Grants Patch Mining Ltd (1987) 12 ACLR 357 , affirmed in Barrack Mines Ltd v Grants Patch Mining Ltd (1987) 12 ACLR 630 ; Biala Pty Ltd v Mallina Holdings Ltd [1990] WAR 371; (1989) 15 ACLR 208 at 215 ; Claremont Petroleum NL v Australian Gas Light Co (1989) 1 ACSR 504 ; P J Norman, “Access to Corporation Information”, (1986) 4 C & SL 149; s 486 of the Corporations Law 1989 (creditors and contributories). Members or officials of trade unions can obtain declarations as to their rights to inspect the books of the union: Norey v Keep [1909] 1 Ch 561 ; Bevan v Webb [1901] 2 Ch 59 ; see also Dodd v Amalgamated Marine Workers’ Union [1923] 2 Ch 236 , affirmed in Dodd v Amalgamated Marine Workers’ Union [1924] 1 Ch 116 . A beneficiary has a right to inspect trust documents: O’Rourke v Darbishire [1920] AC 581 at 626; [1920] All ER Rep 1 ; Re Londonderry’s Settlement [1965] Ch 918 at 935, 937 ; Hartigan Nominees Pty Ltd v Rydge (1992) 29 NSWLR 405 at 443 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 21.2] r 21.2 Order for discovery (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(1), (2) and (3); DCR Part 22, rule 3(1), (2) and (3))

leg:heading.title: Order for discovery (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(1), (2) and (3); DCR Part 22, rule 3(1), (2) and (3))

p.text: The court may order that party B must give discovery to party A of:
documents within a class or classes specified in the order, or
one or more samples (selected in such manner as the court may specify) of documents within such a class.
A class of documents must not be specified in more general terms than the court considers to be justified in the circumstances.
Subject to subrule (2), a class of documents may be specified:
by relevance to one or more facts in issue, or
by description of the nature of the documents and the period within which they were brought into existence, or
in such other manner as the court considers appropriate in the circumstances.
An order for discovery may not be made in respect of a document unless the document is relevant to a fact in issue.
[subr (4) insrt Amendment 13 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[6], effective 5 April 2007]

level.toc-caption: [21.2.5] Classes of documents — no general discovery

heading.title: Classes of documents — no general discovery

p.text: Discovery is limited to documents that are “relevant to a fact in issue” (see [21.1.10] and [21.1.15]) and to classes of documents. The class of documents to be discovered must be specified no more widely than the court considers justified in the circumstances. The purpose of the restriction is to avoid the potential for discovery to give rise to oppressive and disproportionate costs and to impede the “overriding purpose” in CPA s 56: see Palavi v Radio 2UE Sydney Pty Ltd [2011] NSWCA 264; BC201106918 at [101] per Allsop P. The exercise of the court’s discretion under this rule will involve a balancing of the respective interests of the parties, having regard both to the issues in the proceedings and to the surrounding circumstances of the case. In some instances, the nature of the proceedings will justify an order for discovery that classifies documents by their relationship to particular issues — and in these instances the discovery obligation may be similar to the general discovery obligation under the previous rules. In other instances, however, where issues are more narrowly defined or, perhaps where the relevant factual circumstances can be identified, it will be appropriate to classify documents by particular subject matters and thereby limit the extent of the discovery obligation.

The court has a general discretion to require, or limit, discovery consistent with the overriding purpose in CPA s 56: Palavi v Radio 2UE Sydney Pty Ltd [2011] NSWCA 264; BC201106918 at [101] (courts should be alert to the cost, and associated delay and complexity, associated with extensive discovery). Apart from that general discretion, the court may postpone discovery, either entirely or in relation to particular matters, where there is a preliminary issue to be tried, for example, as to liability: Schreiber v Heymann (1894) 63 LJQB 749 ; Fennessy v Clark (1887) 37 Ch D 184. The court may relieve a party from giving discovery where the extent of discovery would be oppressive: Alexander v Fitzpatrick [1981] Qd R 359 ; White & Co v Credit Reform Assn [1905] 1 KB 653 ; Kennedy v Dodson [1895] 1 Ch 334 .

The court may refuse to order, or restrict, discovery or inspection in relation to secret or commercial information, especially where the parties to the proceedings are trade rivals: Attorney-General v North Metropolitan Tramways Co [1892] 3 Ch 70 at 74 ; Mobil Oil Australia Ltd v Guina Developments Pty Ltd [1996] 2 VR 349; cf British Thomson-Houston Co Ltd v Duram Ltd [1915] 1 Ch 823 . See also the general principles as to disclosure of secret information in the course of pre-trial procedures: American Flange & Manufacturing Co Inc v Rheem (Aust) Pty Ltd (No 2) [1965] NSWR 193 and note [21.4.45] .

Discovery against an executor may be ordered in an appropriate case — such as where there is a justification for doubting the adequacy of the executor’s disclosure: Borthwick, Re; Borthwick v Beauvais [1948] Ch 645 ; Reed v Reed [2001] VSC 54; BC200101008 .
Legislation cited in [21.2.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.4.

A party ordered to provide discovery must provide an affidavit certifying belief in the adequacy of discovery and, if legally represented, a solicitor’s certificate of advice about the scope of the discovery obligation: UCPR r 21.4 . Provided there is demonstrable compliance with those requirements the list of documents and the supporting affidavit are generally conclusive as to:

whether the party had any undisclosed documents: Proctor and Gamble Australia Pty Ltd v Medical Research Pty Ltd [2001] NSWSC 183 at [64]–[66]; BC200101311 ; Gardner v Irvin (1878) 4 Ex D 49 ; Jones v Monte Video Gas Co (1880) 5 QBD 556 ;
the relevance of any undisclosed documents: Budden v Wilkinson [1893] 2 QB 432 ; Mogul Steamship Co v McGregor & Co (1886) 2 TLR 752 ;

the grounds stated in support of a claim for privilege from production: Budden v Wilkinson , above; Bewicke v Graham (1881) 7 QBD 400 ; Bulman & Dixon v Young Ehlers & Co (1883) 49 LT 736; Frankenstein v Gavin’s House to House Cycle Cleaning and Insurance Co [1897] 2 QB 62 ; Chowood Ltd v Lyall [1929] 2 Ch 406 .

Nevertheless, the court may permit an application for further discovery, including (though exceptionally: see Fruehauf Finance Corp Ltd v Zurich Australian Insurance Ltd (1990) 20 NSWLR 359 esp at 360 et seq; Ange v Fairfax Media Publications Pty Ltd, above) cross-examination on the verifying affidavit.

An order for further discovery will not be made merely on the basis of a speculative possibility that a party has not disclosed a relevant document: Martell v Victorian Coal Miner’s Assn (1903) 28 VLR 643; 9 ALR 174 ; Pendlebury v O’Neill (1911) 11 SR (NSW) 188 ; Kent Coal Concessions Ltd v Duguid [1910] AC 452; (1910) 79 LJKB 872 . In order to justify an order for further discovery the applicant must specify the document, or class of documents, in respect of which further discovery is sought and must establish reasonable grounds for believing that the documents were, or had been, in the opponent’s possession: Beecham Group Ltd v Bristol-Meyers Co Ltd [1979] VR 273 at 278–82 ; Smith v Goldring (1887) 4 WN (NSW) 13; Hall v Brunton (1894) 10 WN (NSW) 196. Reasonable grounds may be demonstrated where:

there is evidence of admissions by the party making discovery, that they have, or have had, other relevant documents in their possession: Jones v Monte Video Gas Co , above; Kent Coal Concessions Ltd v Duguid [1910] 1 KB 904; (1910) 79 LJKB 423 , affirmed in Kent Coal Concessions Ltd v Duguid [1910] AC 452 (HL). (Relevant admissions may be derived from the pleadings, affidavits and witness statements or from the contents of the discovered documents themselves); Ormerod Grierson & Co v St George’s Ironworks (1906) 95 LT 694 (additional letter referred to in one of the discovered documents);
the form of the original list itself points to the probable existence of other documents;

the documents referred to the list of discovered documents, either by their content, nature or subject matter, also point to the probable existence of other documents: Ace Hire Aust Pty Ltd v ADI Ltd [2006] NSWSC 969; BC200607436 (small number of documents produced in relation to substantial, complex contract with prolonged performance period);

the basis on which the first list was made apparently involves a misconception of the order or the issues by the person who provided the list: British Association of Glass Bottle Manufacturers Ltd v Nettlefold [1912] 1 KB 369 , affirmed in British Association of Glass Bottle Manufacturers Ltd v Nettlefold [1912] AC 709 (HL); Mulley & Marney v Manifold (1959) 103 CLR 341; BC5900640 .
Legislation cited in [21.2.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 5, r 21.1.

As a general rule, discovery can only be ordered between parties to the action: James Nelson & Sons Ltd v Nelson Line (Liverpool) Ltd [1906] 2 KB 217 ; Buxton & Lysaght Pty Ltd v Buxton [1977] 1 NSWLR 285 . Apart from the special provisions of Pt 5 of the UCPR (relating to preliminary discovery), the court cannot order a person who is not a party to the action to give discovery. However, if a person is merely a nominal party, the proceedings may be stayed until the real person conducting the proceedings gives discovery: Willis & Co v Baddeley [1892] 2 QB 324 . But the nominal plaintiff is also liable to make discovery: Wilson v Raffalovich (1881) 7 QBD 553 . Furthermore, despite the general rule that discovery is only appropriate between parties who are formally at issue in the proceedings, any party may make an application for discovery, against any other party to the proceedings under r 21.1 : Re Wynne’s; Mills v Gray [1983] ACLD 394; Barker & Taylor Pty Ltd v Cablemakers (ACT) Pty Ltd [1982] 1 NSWLR 719 ; Cojuanco v Routley [1983] 1 NSWLR 723 . The court will make an order whenever it is necessary to do justice between the parties: Cojuanco v Routley , above; Estate of Wynne; Mills v Gray , above; Barker & Taylor Pty Ltd v Cablemakers (ACT) Pty Ltd , above. As between defendants, an entitlement to discovery could arise where each sought to attribute the injury to the plaintiff to the negligence of the other, or where each alleged that the negligent person was the other’s servant: Brown v Watkins (1885) 16 QBD 125 ; Shaw v Smith (1886) 18 QBD 193 (no issue between defendants); Spokes v Grosvenor and West End Railway Terminus Hotel Co Ltd [1897] 2 QB 124; [1895–9] All ER Rep Ext 1779 ; Cory v Cory [1923] 1 Ch 90 ; Molloy v Kilby (1880) 15 Ch D 162 ; Birchal v Birch Crisp & Co [1913] 2 Ch 375 .

Discovery may be ordered against a party who has entered a submitting appearance. However, the absence of disputed issues between particular parties may indicate either that discovery should be limited or that it is in fact not justified in the circumstances: Murex Diagnostics Australia Pty Ltd v Chiron Corp (1995) 55 FCR 194; 128 ALR 525 .

level.toc-caption: [21.2.35] Prerogative orders — discovery in proceedings for

heading.title: Prerogative orders — discovery in proceedings for

p.text: Although in proceedings for prerogative orders the court’s function is supervisory, some investigation of the facts may be involved, and there is power to order discovery, even if it need not often be exercised: R v State Secretary for the Home Dept; Ex parte Herbage (No 2) [1987] QB 1077; [1987] 2 WLR 226 ; Re Federal Cmr of Taxation; Ex parte Swiss Aluminium Australia Ltd (1987) 14 ALD 106; 72 ALR 247 . Where there is little common ground between the parties as to the primary facts, discovery is appropriate and where the subject matter of the proceedings is complex, it is often preferable to make an order for discovery in reasonably wide terms because the discovering party will then be obliged to make an informed judgment on a matter well within its knowledge: Re Federal Cmr of Taxation; Ex parte Swiss Aluminium Australia Ltd , above; see also Federal Cmr of Taxation v Hydrocarbon Products Pty Ltd (1987) 14 FCR 359; 72 ALR 391 (which relates to the provision of discovery in taxation proceedings).

level.toc-caption: [21.2.40] Time for discovery — discovery before close of pleading

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.2.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 5, r 15.19(1)(b), r 25.3.

heading.title: Time for discovery — discovery before close of pleading

p.text: The rule confers a general power to order discovery and is complemented by special rules that permit discovery and preservation of documents prior to the commencement of substantive proceedings: see Pt 5 (Preliminary Discovery) and r 25.3 (preservation of property) and especially [25.3.20] (Anton Piller orders). The combined effect of the general terms of the power, and the special rules, is to permit orders for discovery to be ordered at any stage of the proceedings. It will usually be most conducive the efficient and economical conduct of the litigation to postpone discovery until the issues have been defined by the close of pleadings and the appropriate scope and generality of discovery can be best determined. For that reason there is a general practice that a party will not be granted discovery before the close of pleadings. This general practice is, of course, subject to appropriate exceptions: Latec Finance Pty Ltd v Jury [1960] NSWR 321; (1960) 77 WN (NSW) 674 . Sometimes likely issues in the litigation, and the required scope of discovery may have been sufficiently established in the statement of claim: Gale v Denman Picture Houses Ltd [1930] 1 KB 588 ; Speyside Estate & Trust Co Ltd v Wraymond Freeman (Blenders) Ltd [1950] Ch 96 ; Gollin Holdings Ltd v Adcock [1981] 1 NSWLR 691; (1981) 5 ACLR 750 . In other instances, analogous to the situations in which UCPR Pt 5 permits preliminary discovery, it may be appropriate to order limited discovery in order to permit a plaintiff to properly plead its claim: Kaiser v George Laurens (NSW) Pty Ltd [1982] 1 NSWLR 294 (defamation — discovery ordered of details of publication); Ahmed v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 11; BC200600202 (defamation — discovery of international publication required to provide particulars required by UCPR r 15.19(1)(b) ).
Legislation cited in [21.2.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 233.

An order for discovery will generally not be appropriate in winding-up proceedings — especially if the ground relied upon is mere non-payment of a statutory demand: Re a Debtor (No 7 of 1910) [1910] 2 KB 59 ; Re ABT Holdings Pty Ltd (1979) 4 ACLR 40 . However, proceedings under s 233 of the Corporations Act 2001 (which relate to winding up where the affairs of a company are alleged to be being conducted in an oppressive manner), potentially raise a range of issues and in proceedings of that kind, an order for discovery will often be appropriate: Re Australian Marinas (A’asia) Pty Ltd [1975] VR 372 ; Re ABT Holdings Pty Ltd , above.

level.toc-caption: [21.2.50] Equity Division proceedings — Practice Note SC Eq 11 — discovery only after disclosure of evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.2.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56.

heading.title: Equity Division proceedings — Practice Note SC Eq 11 — discovery only after disclosure of evidence

p.text: Practice Note SC Eq 11 commenced on 26 March 2012. It applies to all proceedings in the Division, other than those in the Commercial Arbitration List. The practice note is intended to set out the general approach that the court will take to the exercise of its discretion under UCPR r 21.2. The practice note reflects long standing concern about the potential for the extent and cost of the discovery process to be disproportionate to the proper, expeditious and economical resolution of the proceedings: see [21.2.5]; Armstrong Strategic Management and Marketing Pty Ltd v Expense Reduction Analysts Group Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 393; BC201202767 at [65]–[66]; Leighton International v Hodges [2012] NSWSC 458; BC201203283 at [4]–[7].

Clause 4 of the practice note provides that, until the parties have served their evidence, the court will not make an order for disclosure of documents (including orders to which the parties themselves consent) unless there are “exceptional circumstances necessitating disclosure”. The purpose of the limitation expressed in the practice note is to confine discovery to the extent necessary to the proper resolution of the proceedings.
Any application for an order for disclosure, even an application for consent orders, must be supported by an affidavit setting out:
the reason why disclosure is necessary for the resolution of the real issues in dispute
the classes of documents sought to be disclosed
the likely cost of disclosure.

“exceptional circumstances” The concept of “exceptional circumstances” defies definition. What it essentially conveys is a requirement that the particular circumstances have a material character that is more than circumstances regularly, routinely or normally encountered. It does not require that the circumstances must be unique, or very rare. Leighton International v Hodges [2012] NSWSC 458; BC201203283 at [19]–[20] . The characterisation in any particular case has to involve consideration of that nature and purpose of the requirement, and both the postulated reason for, and the consequences of, its application in the particular case: Leighton International v Hodges [2012] NSWSC 458; BC201203283 at [19]–[20] ; Leda Manorstead Pty Ltd v Chief Cmr of State Revenue [2012] NSWSC 913; BC201206359 at [17] . It may be a useful approach to contemplate that circumstances may be characterised as “exceptional” if they necessitate disclosure — in order to achieve the objectives of the overriding purpose of CPA s 56 : Leighton International v Hodges [2012] NSWSC 458; BC201203283 at [19]–[20] ; Danihel v Manning [2012] NSWSC 556; BC201203425 at [16] (“to show exceptional circumstances, it would be necessary to demonstrate the necessity to obtain documents to fairly prepare a case for trial”).

Exceptional circumstances have been held to exist, for the purposes of the present rule, where information necessary to a party’s case was solely within the knowledge of the party from whom disclosure was sought); Naiman Clarke Ltd atf Naiman Clarke Trust v Tuccia [2012] NSWSC 314; BC201203367 at [26] ; Mempoll Pty Ltd, Anakin Pty Ltd and Gold Kings (Australia) Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 1057; BC201206908 (highly relevant information was solely or largely in the possession of the other party).

“necessitating disclosure” The basic idea underlying the practice is that the concept of “necessity” will ordinarily be best assessed in light of the material actually in contest between the parties, as revealed by their proposed evidence. The concept of “necessity”, in this context, is directed at what is reasonably required to determine the proceedings appropriately, in accordance with the overriding purpose in CPA s 56: Leighton International v Hodges [2012] NSWSC 458; BC201203283 at [21]–[23], see [22.1.15] and [22.1.17].

The practice note does not preclude the parties from implementing private agreements for the disclosure of documents. Indeed, parties obligations under CPA s 56(3) and (3A), point to the desirability of a measure of co-operation between the parties: see Leighton International v Hodges [2012] NSWSC 458; BC201203283 at [11] and following per McDougall J. In the absence of co-operation, however, the requirements of the practice note will apply to any order for disclosure, including orders relating to enforcing compliance with notices to produce issued under UCPR rr 21.10 or 34.1: Owners Strata Plan SP 69567 v Baseline Constructions Pty Ltd [2012 NSWSC 502; BC201203158 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 21.3] r 21.3 List of documents to be prepared (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(5) and (6); DCR Part 22, rule 3(5) and (6))

leg:heading.title: List of documents to be prepared (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(5) and (6); DCR Part 22, rule 3(5) and (6))

p.text: Party B must comply with an order for discovery by serving on party A a list of documents that deals with all of the documents (other than excluded documents) referred to in the order.
[subr (1) am Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[13], effective 30 September 2005]
The list of documents:
must be divided into two parts:
Part 1 relating to documents in the possession of party B, and
Part 2 relating to documents that are not, but that within the last 6 months prior to the commencement of the proceedings have been, in the possession of party B, and
must include a brief description (by reference to nature and date or period) of each document or group of documents and, in the case of a group, the number of documents in that group, and

must specify, against the description of each document or group in Part 2 of the list of documents, the person (if any) who party B believes to be in possession of the document or group of documents, and
must identify any document that is claimed to be a privileged document, and specify the circumstances under which the privilege is claimed to arise.
Party B must comply with the requirements of subrule (1):
within 28 days after an order for discovery is made, or
within such other period (whether more or less than 28 days) as the order may specify.
The approved form is Form 11 : List of Documents.

level.toc-caption: [21.3.7] The structure of the discovery list — possession, location and privilege

heading.title: The structure of the discovery list — possession, location and privilege

p.text: The list of discovered documents must distinguish between documents that are in the possession of the party (Pt 1 of the discovery list) and documents that have been in the party’s possession at any time within the 6 months before the commencement of the proceedings (Pt 2 of the discovery list). (Where the documents are no longer in the possession of the party, the list must specify in whose possession the documents are believed to be.) The list must also identify any documents for which privilege is claimed and specify the factual basis for the privilege claimed. Failure to comply with the substance of that requirement may attract corrective orders, and a costs sanction, but will not itself justify rejection of an otherwise justified privilege claim: see Barnes v Cmr of Taxation (2007) 242 ALR 601; [2007] FCAFC 88; BC200707308 (inadequate affidavit evidence to support of claim for privilege — claim upheld after inspection); Bailey v Dept of Land and Water Conservation [2009] NSWCA 100; BC200903503 at [39]–[41] and [45] . As to what constitutes a “privileged” document see [21.5.55] .

Where discovery is provided in the form of an electronic list, parties should attempt to agree on the list format. The nature of such a list, and the document identification style suggested in Practice Note SC Gen 7 Use of Technology Annex 2 may involve significant departure from the list format contemplated by the present rule.

level.toc-caption: [21.3.10] The form of the list of discovered documents

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.3.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.5.

heading.title: The form of the list of discovered documents

p.text: The obligations of the discovering party in relation to the identification and inspection of discovered documents are set out in UCPR r 21.5 . Those obligations require sensible judgment to be applied in compiling any discovery list and in making the documents available. Depending on the particular case, this requirement may mean that the documents should be in chronological order, or that they be grouped by author, subject matter or type of document (for example, accounting records). However the discovery list is arranged, all the documents listed must be identified in a way that makes it possible to require the production of particular documents.
Legislation cited in [21.3.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 17.5, r 21.5(1)(b).

The requirement for particular identification of discovered documents serves two purposes. First, particular identification, by a practice of numbering and description will permit the convenient production of particular specified documents: see UCPR r 21.5(1)(b) ; Taylor v Batten, above; Bristol Corporation v Cox (1884) 26 Ch D 678 at 681 ; Budden v Wilkinson [1893] 2 QB 432 ; Price v Price (1879) 48 LJ Ch 215; Miller v Kennedy (1892) 14 ALT 37 ; cf O’Brien v McKenzie (1900) 21 LR (NSW) Eq 117. Second, the party obtaining discovery (party A) is entitled to have the benefit of any admission that may be involved in a proper description of the documents. Party A is also entitled to be given proper notice of the contentions of the discovering party (party B) about the significance of particular documents: see r 17.5 of the UCPR (which relates to the admissions deemed to result from discovery). This consideration is particularly important, and the need for a proper description is underscored, where a claim for privilege is made in relation to a particular document: JN Taylor Holdings Ltd (in liq) v Bond (1991) 57 SASR 21 .

level.toc-caption: [21.3.15] The form of particular identification — voluminous discovery and electronically stored information

heading.title: The form of particular identification — voluminous discovery and electronically stored information

p.text: The requirement for particular identification would ideally lead to the separate description and numbering of each individual document: Hill v Hart-Davis (1884) 26 Ch D 470 at 472 ; Cooke v Smith [1891] 1 Ch 509 at 522 . Where classes or groups of documents are discovered, it will often be both convenient and sufficient merely to provide a meaningful description of the class, state the number of individual documents or pages, and physically number the documents themselves: Taylor v Batten (1878) 4 QBD 85 ; Morris v Edwards (1890) 15 App Cas 309 ; Ricketson v Smith (1896) 17 NSWLR Eq 209; Milbank v Milbank [1900] 1 Ch 376 at 383 . Where voluminous discovery is involved additional measures may be required. If the physical documents for discovery exceed 500, the court may require the parties to consider the appropriateness of providing discovery and inspection in the form of an electronic database. Where the discoverable documents include electronically stored information, parties must endeavour to agree on the scope of discovery required, the format of their respective discovery databases and lists and the style of document identification. Matters relevant to the format of discovery databases, and the exchange of electronic data generally (including court documents) are outlined in Practice Note SC Gen 7 Use of Technology — particularly Annex 1. A range of suggested fields relevant to the suitable identification of electronic data for the purpose of discovery is set out in Practice Note SC Gen 7 Annex 2.
Legislation cited in [21.3.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 3.

The discovery obligation applies to documents in the “possession” of the discovering party. “Possession” of documents is defined to include custody or power: see CPA s 3 . Typically the discovery obligation has been regarded as extending to any documents within a party’s “possession, custody or power”. There is an element of tautology in this expression, but it serves to indicate that the obligation is not confined to documents that are in the party’s immediate physical custody, nor those in the party’s sole possession: Turner v Davies [1981] 2 NSWLR 324 . The concept of “possession” in the present rule is likely to be interpreted just as expansively. Consequently, discoverable documents include those:

which are or have been in the possession or power of any agent for the party making discovery: Murray v Walter [1839] Cr & Ph 114 at 125; 54 RR 232; Swanston v Lishman (1881) 45 LT 360 ; Lazarus v Mozley (1859) 5 Jur NS 1119;

which are or have been in the party’s possession or power as agent or servant for another or others: Alfred Crompton Amusement Machines Ltd v Customs and Excise Cmrs (No 2) [1974] AC 405; [1973] 2 All ER 1169 ; Turner v Davies [1981] 2 NSWLR 324 ; Rochfort v Trade Practices Commission (1982) 153 CLR 134; 43 ALR 659 ;

which, though not in the party’s immediate physical possession or custody, the party has a right to obtain from another person. As to documents in the custody of a subsidiary company: see B v B [1978] Fam 181; [1978] 3 WLR 624 ; Lonrho Ltd v Shell Petroleum Co Ltd [1980] 1 WLR 627 ;

which the party would be likely to obtain if it made a request to the owner of the documents: Sabre Corp v Russ Kalvin’s Hair Care (1993) 46 FCR 428 at 432; 124 ALR 400 ; Palmdale Insurance Ltd (in liq) v L Grollo & Co Pty Ltd [1987] VR 113 at 115 .

Where a party no longer has a document in its possession, the discovery procedures may be utilised to trace the location of the document: (Theodore v Australian Postal Commission [1988] VR 272 ; Lethbridge v Cronk (1875) 23 WR 703; Lacharme v Quartz Rock Mining Co (1862) 158 ER 832; 1 H & C 134), in which case the power of the court shall extend to the making of ancillary orders covering the cost of production: see Roach v Page (t/as Freehill Hollingdale and Page) (SC(NSW) 22 April 1998 unreported; BC9802253); Palmdale Insurance Ltd v L Grollo Pty Ltd [1999] NSWSC 1026 . The party providing discovery may be required to disclose the contents of the document, where they are known to it: Australian Federal Police v Propend Finance Pty Ltd (1997) 188 CLR 501; 141 ALR 545 per Brennan J; Ramsey v Ramsey [1956] 1 WLR 542; Wolverhampton New Waterworks Co v Hawkesford (1859) 6 CBNS 336; 141 ER 486 .

The fact that the party providing discovery is entitled to a lien over the documents may be a valid ground for objecting to production, if the lien is available against the party seeking production, but not if production is sought by third persons: Bolster v McCallum [1966] 2 NSWR 660; (1966) 85 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 281 ; see 51 ALJ 158 or if the production of the documents affects the rights of third persons: see Hughes v Hughes [1958] P 221; [1958] 2 All ER 366; 2 WLR 934 . The right to object to production depends on whether the party against whom the lien is asserted wrongfully terminated the underlying transaction (for example, a contract of retainer) out of which the claim arose: In re Rapid Road Transit Company [1909] 1 Ch 96 ; Bechara v Atie [2005] NSWCA 268; BC200505869 .

The court may override the objection if production is necessary for disposing fairly of the issues that arise in the proceedings: Woodworth v Conroy [1976] QB 884; [1976] 1 All ER 107; [1976] 2 WLR 338 (fee dispute between accountants and former clients); In the Marriage of Rhode (1985) 9 Fam LR 159; In the Marriage of Bolger (1985) 10 Fam LR 523; 82 FLR 46; (1985) FLC 91-646 ; Tyneside Managements Pty Ltd v Hammersmith Management Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 156; BC201101895 (lien claimed by subpoena recipient against former client — access limited to other party in proceedings). And if the underlying transaction had been terminated by the party asserting the lien, the court may order the production of the contentious documents, and require the party seeking production to provide substitute security for the lien: Blander v Kemp Strang Lawyers Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 48; BC200602515 .

Freedom of information legislation may be relevant to the discovery process either because one of the parties is a document repository to which the legislation applies (and the legislation imposes more extensive disclosure obligations) or because an opposing party can invoke the legislation to obtain documents from such a third-party repository. In the former category of cases, the mere fact that an FOI request is made after orders for discovery in the proceedings does not necessarily constitute an abuse of process — though it may do so if the effect of the request is to interfere with the conduct of the litigation or subject the discovering party to duplicated obligations: Johnson Tiles Pty Ltd v Esso Australia Ltd (No 3) (2000) 98 FCR 311; 174 ALR 701 . In the second category of cases, documents a party may obtain pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act 1982 (Cth) (eg, copies of tax returns) may also be discoverable: Kirby v Southern Pacific Hotel Corp Ltd (NSWSC, Allen M, 5 May 1983, unreported). However, it is appropriate to observe that the question whether a document that can be obtained by the exercise of a statutory power is within the “control” of a person for the purposes of discovery has generated some conflicting authorities. The decision in Kirby, above, is apparently consistent with Palmdale Insurance Ltd (in liq) v L Grollo & Co Pty Ltd [1987] VR 113 . Neither of these decisions were followed in Midalco Pty Ltd v Simpson (WASC, Full Court, 5 June 1987, unreported, BC8701742) and Lewandowski v Lovell (1994) 11 WAR 124; BC9401588 . The decision in Palmdale , above was distinguished in Theodore v Australian Postal Commission [1988] VR 272 . As to the scope of the directions power in permitting orders requiring parties to obtain documents not currently within their actual current possession or control, see [2.1.10] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 21.4] r 21.4 Affidavit and certificate supporting list of documents (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(5), (6) and (7); DCR Part 22, rule 3(5), (6) and (7))

leg:heading.title: Affidavit and certificate supporting list of documents (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(5), (6) and (7); DCR Part 22, rule 3(5), (6) and (7))

p.text: The list of documents must be accompanied by:
a supporting affidavit, and
if party B has a solicitor, by a solicitor’s certificate of advice.
See rule 35.3 as to who may make such an affidavit.
The affidavit referred to in subrule (1)(a) must state that the deponent:
has made reasonable inquiries as to the documents referred to in the order, and

believes that there are no documents (other than excluded documents) falling within any of the classes specified in the order that are, or that within the last 6 months before the commencement of the proceedings have been, in the possession of party B (other than those referred to in Part 1 or 2 of the list of documents), and
believes that the documents in Part 1 of the list of documents are within the possession of party B, and
believes that the documents in Part 2 of the list of documents are within the possession of the persons (if any) respectively specified in that Part, and
as to any document in Part 2 of the list of documents in respect of which no such person is specified, has no belief as to whose possession the document is in,
and must state, in respect of any document that is claimed to be a privileged document, the facts relied on as establishing the existence of the privilege.
The solicitor’s certificate of advice referred to in subrule (1)(b) must state that the solicitor:
has advised party B as to the obligations arising under an order for discovery (and if party B is a corporation, which officers of party B have been so advised), and

is not aware of any documents within any of the classes specified in the order (other than excluded documents) that are, or that within the last 6 months before the commencement of the proceedings have been, in the possession of party B (other than those referred to in Part 1 or 2 of the list of documents).
Legislation cited in [21.4.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 35.3.

The list of documents is to be accompanied by an affidavit from an appropriate person verifying the contents of the list. Where the party is an individual, they should make the affidavit personally. An affidavit verifying a list of documents cannot be properly sworn by a person who holds a power of attorney from a party who is a natural person: Clauss v Pir [1988] Ch 267 . Where the party providing discovery is a person under legal incapacity, the tutor should swear the affidavit. Where the party is the Crown, a corporation or an unincorporated association, the deponent must be selected from the eligible persons provided for in r 35.3 of the UCPR. If any documents are claimed to be privileged, the deponent must state the facts relied on to establish the basis for the privilege.

level.toc-caption: [21.4.7] Verification — discovery of electronically stored data

heading.title: Verification — discovery of electronically stored data

p.text: The rules presuppose the preparation of a discovery list, and inspection of documents, in “hard copy” form. Where the discovered documents are voluminous, discovery and inspection in an electronic storage format may be more practical, convenient and economic: Richard Crookes Constructions Pty Ltd v F Hannan (Properties) Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 142; BC200901595 (electronic discovery ordered — more efficient and cost effective given the volume of documents to be discovered). In addition, some discoverable documents may only exist as electronically stored information. Practice Note SC Gen 7 addresses the issues relevant to discovery and inspection of electronic data. Verification of discovery provided in the form of electronic data may still involve the production of a “hard copy” of the electronic discovery list. Alternatively, verification may be more appropriately provided by reference to the manner, occasion and form of service of the electronic list itself: see Practice Note SC Gen 7 para 19.
Legislation cited in [21.4.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.6.

The solicitor for the party giving discovery must certify to having explained the requirements for disclosure to that party and that the solicitor is not aware of any documents in the possession, custody or power of the client other than those referred to in the list of documents. This requirement reinforces the positive duty of the solicitor to ensure that all relevant documents are disclosed: Ferguson v Mackaness Produce Pty Ltd [1970] 2 NSWR 66 at 68 ; Rockwell Machine Tool Co Ltd v EP Barrus (Concessionaires) Ltd [1968] 2 All ER 98 at 99; [1968] 1 WLR 693 . In discharging that duty the solicitor must both properly advise the client and also consider the list of documents. The solicitor must make an independent appraisal of the case, assess what the client is likely to have and form an opinion as to whether any material has been left out: Woods v Martins Bank Ltd [1959] 1 QB 55; [1958] 3 All ER 166 . If the solicitor forms the opinion that the list is incomplete, the matter must be brought to the client’s attention. If the client insists on delivery of an incomplete list, or will not give sufficient information for an accurate list to be prepared, the solicitor must withdraw from the case. If a discoverable document is found after discovery has been given, the solicitor ’s duty is to serve a supplementary list of documents: Myers v Elman [1940] AC 282; [1939] 4 All ER 484 . See also UCPR r 21.6 .
As to the circumstances in which an an alleged in sufficiency of discovery may justify the making of and order for further discovery see [21.2.20] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 21.5] r 21.5 Documents to be made available (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(9) and (10); DCR Part 22, rule 3(9) and (10))

leg:heading.title: Documents to be made available (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(9) and (10); DCR Part 22, rule 3(9) and (10))

p.text: Subject to the requirements of any Act or law, Party B must ensure that the documents described in Part 1 of the list of documents (other than privileged documents):
are physically kept and arranged in a way that makes the documents readily accessible and capable of convenient inspection by party A, and
are identified in a way that enables particular documents to be readily retrieved,
from the time the list of documents is served on party A until the time the trial of the proceedings is completed.
[subr (1) subst Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 9 June 2006]
Within 21 days after service of the list of documents, or within such other period or at such other times as the court may specify, party B must, on request by party A:
produce for party A’s inspection the documents described in Part 1 of the list of documents (other than privileged documents), and

make available to party A a person who is able to, and does on party A’s request, explain the way the documents are arranged and assist in locating and identifying particular documents or classes of documents, and
provide facilities for the inspection and copying of such of the documents (other than privileged documents) as are not capable of being photocopied, and
provide photocopies of, or facilities for the photocopying of, such of the documents as are capable of being photocopied, subject to:
party A’s solicitor undertaking to pay the reasonable costs of providing those photocopies or facilities, or
if party A has no solicitor, party A providing to party B an amount not less than a reasonable estimate of the reasonable costs of providing those photocopies or facilities.

As a general proposition, privilege claims (and other proper grounds of objection to inspection) relate to the disclosure of the contents of documents rather than to disclosure of the fact of the existence of the document: Spokes v Grosvenor and West End Railway Terminus Hotel Co Ltd [1897] 2 QB 124; [1895–9] All ER Rep Ext 1779 ; National Association of Operative Plasterers v Smithies [1906] AC 434 . Only in a rare case will an order be made that completely excuses a party from the obligation to provide discovery: cf EL Bell Packaging Pty Ltd v Allied Seafoods Ltd (1990) 4 ACSR 85 (where the only means of protecting the right against self-incrimination is to excuse the party completely from discovery, the party may be completely excused); Griffin v Sogelease Australia Ltd (2003) 57 NSWLR 257; [2003] NSWCA 158; BC200303257 (discovery not ordered); R v DCT (WA); Ex parte Briggs (1987) 13 FCR 389; 71 ALR 86 ; Glynn v Houston (1836) 1 Keen 329; 48 ER 333 .
Legislation cited in [21.5.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 17.5(4), r 21.5(2).

A party who provides discovery must keep the documents and make them (other than privileged documents) available for inspection within 21 days after service of the list of documents, or within such other period as the court specifies. The discovered documents must be available for production at the trial: see r 17.5(4) of the UCPR (they are deemed to be subject to a notice to produce). Until completion of the trial of the proceedings, the documents are to be kept identified in a way that enables particular documents to be readily retrieved: see [21.3.15] . The documents produced for inspection must be arranged in a way that makes them readily accessible and capable of convenient inspection. As well, r 21.5(2) obliges the discovering party to make a person available who can explain the way in which the documents are arranged and assist in their location and identification. The discovering party must also provide facilities for the inspection and copying of the documents.
Legislation cited in [21.5.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.5(2)(c).

A party will usually be ordered to produce the documents for inspection at the office of the discovering party’s solicitor. However, production may be ordered at any place that is appropriate in the circumstances: Prestney v Corp of Colchester (1883) 24 Ch D 376 ; Whyte v Ahrens (1884) 50 LT 344 (production in Japan ordered); Broken Hill and Argentine Smelting Co v Foreman (1896) 12 WN (NSW) 169 . An order may be made that the documents be produced to the court and inspected there: Leslie v Cave [1896] WN 162 and now r 21.5(2)(c) . An order may be made requiring the documents to be delivered to a handwriting expert: Re Saxton (dec’d); Johnson v Saxton [1962] 2 All ER 618; [1962] 1 WLR 859 . Only in exceptional circumstances will the court permit a person who is not party’s counsel or solicitor, nor an employee of the solicitor, nor a professional expert, to inspect discovered documents: Davies v Eli Lilly & Co [1987] 1 All ER 801 .

level.toc-caption: [21.5.20] Client legal privilege — nature and scope

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.5.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 118, s 119, s 132.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 576.

heading.title: Client legal privilege — nature and scope

p.text: Client legal privilege is a rule of substantive law which permits a person to resist privileged information being put into evidence against their consent: Daniels Corporation International Pty Ltd v Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (2002) 213 CLR 543; 192 ALR 561; [2002] HCA 49; BC200206568 at [9] . (It also provides, in conjunction with the rules, a basis for resisting disclosure of privileged documents: see [1.9.3] and [21.5.55] .) Client legal privilege applies to confidential communications that occurred, and to confidential documents that were created, for the “dominant purpose” of a client obtaining legal advice: Evidence Act 1995 s 118 . It also applies to confidential communications that occurred, and to confidential documents that were created, for the “dominant purpose” of a client obtaining legal services in relation to pending or anticipated litigation: Evidence Act 1995 s 119 ; Esso Australia Resources Ltd v FCT (1999) 201 CLR 49; 168 ALR 123; [1999] HCA 67; BC9908417 ; Baker v Campbell (1983) 153 CLR 52; 49 ALR 385; BC8300114 ; Grant v Downs (1976) 135 CLR 674; 11 ALR 577; BC7600095 ; Attorney-General (NT) v Maurice (1986) 161 CLR 475; 69 ALR 31; BC8601398 ; Anderson v Bank of British Columbia (1876) 2 Ch D 644 : compare Re L (a minor) (police investigation: privilege) [1997] AC 16; [1996] 2 All ER 78 (litigation privilege not available in non-adversarial investigation proceedings). Both the “legal advice” and “litigation” aspects of the privilege can apply to documents even though the specific communication is not between lawyer and client: Dingle v Commonwealth Development Bank (1989) 23 FCR 63; 91 ALR 239 at 242 and see Evidence Act 1995 ss 118 and 119 . Where it applies, the privilege is that of the client. If the client is a corporation the privilege cannot be claimed personally by officers of the corporation: Baker v Evans (1987) 77 ALR 565 ; R v Davies (1921) 21 SR (NSW) 311; 38 WN (NSW) 90 ; Lake Cumbeline Pty Ltd v Effem Foods Pty Ltd (t/as Uncle Ben's of Australia) (1994) 126 ALR 58; (1994) 13 ACLC 55; BC9400006 (privilege may pass to the Australian Securities Commission pursuant to Corporations Act 2001 s 576 ). If a witness or a party may have grounds for asserting the privilege, a court must satisfy itself that the person is aware of the right to claim privilege: Evidence Act 1995 s 132 .

level.toc-caption: [21.5.25] Client legal privilege — confidential communications for the purpose of legal advice

heading.title: Client legal privilege — confidential communications for the purpose of legal advice

p.text: Client legal privilege only applies to confidential communications and documents. The mere fact the persons involved in the communication are solicitor and client is not a sufficient basis to demonstrate confidentiality and attract the privilege: Minter v Priest [1930] AC 558 . Communications will be sufficiently confidential to attract the privilege if either the maker or the recipient was under an obligation (irrespective of whether the obligation was legally binding) not to disclose its contents: s 117 of the Evidence Act 1995. The requirement of confidentiality may be demonstrated by either the nature of the communication or the circumstances in which it occurs: Trade Practices Commission v Sterling (1979) 36 FLR 244 ; TNT Management v Trade Practices Commission (1983) 47 ALR 693; (1983) ATPR ¶40-366 . The privilege extends to documents that have been provided confidentially for the broad purpose of legal advice even though particular documents do not actually contain legal advice: Balabel v Air India [1988] 1 Ch 317; [1988] 2 All ER 246 . It also extends to advice “about what should prudently and sensibly be done in a relevant legal context” even if it does not involve advice about actual legal rights and obligations: Three Rivers District Council v Governor & Company of the Bank of England (No 6) [2005] 1 AC 610; [2004] 4 All ER 948; [2004] UKHL 48 ; DSE (Holdings) Pty Ltd v InterTAN Inc (2003) 135 FCR 151; 203 ALR 348; [2003] FCA 1191; BC200306380 at [52] . The “legal advice” aspect of the privilege is capable of applying where there is no actual contract of retainer, so long as the client honestly and reasonably believes the other person is acting as the client’s legal advisor: Global Funds Management (NSW) Ltd v Rooney (1994) 36 NSWLR 122; 15 ACSR 368; BC9403374 . The privilege may also apply to communications with a legal advisor who is an employee of the person claiming the privilege: see [21.5.27] .

level.toc-caption: [21.5.27] Client legal privilege — legally qualified employees and in-house lawyers

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.5.27] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 117.

heading.title: Client legal privilege — legally qualified employees and in-house lawyers

p.text: Client legal privilege may apply to communications between a legal advisor and their partners or employer if (i) the communications are confidential, and sufficiently relate to the legal adviser’s independent and disinterested exercise of their professional skills and obligations, and (ii) the employee is legally qualified and amenable to relevant professional practice obligations.

Some work of employed lawyers may be indistinguishable from the work of private legal practitioners. Other aspects of an employee’s function may include different administrative, supervisory and management responsibilities. In order to attract client legal privilege the communications, or documents, in question must have been made or prepared in confidence and arise from the relationship of lawyer and client: Waterford v Commonwealth (1987) 163 CLR 54 at 96; 71 ALR 673; 12 ALD 741; BC8701785 ; AWB Ltd v Cole (No 5) (2006) 234 ALR 651; 155 FCR 30; [2006] FCA 1234; BC200607325 at [44] ; Priest v New South Wales [2006] NSWSC 1281; BC200609706 at [28] (report prepared by legally qualified police officer — police internal investigation — report prepared for the dominant purpose of administrative review — not privileged); Commonwealth v Vance (2005) 158 ACTR 47 at [24] . Advice given by in-house lawyers that is outside the confidential solicitor-client relationship is not protected: R v Shirose (1999) 133 CCC (3d) 257 at 288–9 ; Vance , above, at [28]. See also Priest v New South Wales [2006] NSWSC 1281; BC200609706 at [29] . The application and scope of the privilege in any particular case may depend on affirmative evidence establishing that the “in house” legal adviser functioned as an objective and independent legal adviser in relation to the contentious documents and communications: Waterford v Commonwealth (1987) 163 CLR 54 at 62; 71 ALR 673; BC8701785 ; Telstra Corporation Ltd v Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (No 2) [2007] FCA 1445; BC200707832 at [12] and [36] (absence of evidence of relationship — claim refused); Rich v Harrington (2007) 245 ALR 106; [2007] FCA 1987; BC200710886 (legal adviser with a personal interest in claim against partnership — claim rejected).

The privilege potentially applies so long as the employed lawyer has been admitted to practice and, as such, is amenable to professional standards and discipline Attorney-General (NT) v Kearney & Northern Land Council (1985) 158 CLR 500 at 510; 61 ALR 55; (1985) 59 ALJR 749; BC8501109 per Gibbs CJ. Subsequently in Waterford v Commonwealth (1987) 163 CLR 54; 71 ALR 673; 12 ALD 741; BC8701785 Deane and Dawson JJ expressed views that the privilege only applied if the employed solicitor was “qualified to practice” (at CLR 96) or either held a current practising certificate or worked under the supervision of such a person (at CLR 81). Subsequently in Commonwealth v Vance (2005) 158 ACTR 47 at [23]–[35]; [2005] ACTCA 35; BC200506118 , the ACT Court of Appeal (Gray, Connolly and Tamberlin JJ) held that admission to practice, rather than possession of a current practising certificate, was sufficient to permit the privilege to apply an essential precondition to the availability of legal professional privilege: at [23]–[35]. The same view was later taken by Young J in AWB Ltd v Cole (No 5) (2006) 234 ALR 651 at [44]; (2006) 155 FCR 30; [2006] FCA 1234; BC200607325 — citing other similar cases in Candacal Pty Ltd v Industry Research & Development Board (2005) 223 ALR 284; (2005) 59 ATR 615; [2005] FCA 649; BC200503404 at [99] per Lee J ; Australian Hospital Care (Pindara) Pty Ltd v Duggan [1999] VSC 131; BC9902660 at [111] per Gillard J , and in McKinnon and Secretary, Department of Family and Community Services (2004) 86 ALD 780; 40 AAR 255; [2004] AATA 1365; BC200410937 at [51] per Downes J. It is the position that applies under Evidence Act s 117 — because of the definitions of “client”, “lawyer” and “Australian lawyer” in that legislation: see [51,065.15] .
Legislation cited in [21.5.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 122.

Client legal privilege does not apply to objective facts that come to the knowledge of the lawyer during the course of the relationship: National Crime Authority v S (1991) 29 FCR 203; 100 ALR 151 . Accordingly, the name of the lawyer’s client does not fall within the scope of privilege: Bursill v Tanna (1885) 16 QBD 1 ; Cook v Leonard [1954] VLR 591; [1954] ALR 987 ; Southern Cross Commodities Pty Ltd (in liq) v Crimis [1984] VR 697 . Similarly, the privilege does not prevent legal advisors from giving evidence about matters observed by them, for example, the fact that alterations were made to the contents of a document: Brown v Foster (1857) 1 H & N 736 and see also Ex parte Campbell; Re Cathcart (1870) LR 5 Ch App 703; Re Furney [1964] ALR 814; (1964) 20 ABC 166 ; Re Arnott (1888) 60 LT 109 ; Field v Cmr for Railways for New South Wales (1957) 99 CLR 285 at 291–3; 65 ALR (CN) 1055a (which provides an unusual illustration of a similar proposition in the context of without prejudice communications). Privilege will not prevent disclosure of a videotape recording of things that would constitute primary evidence in the proceedings: J-Corp Pty Ltd v Australian Builders’ Labourers’ Federated Union of Workers (WA) (No 1) (1992) 38 FCR 452; 110 ALR 510 . Nor does privilege attach to notes made of proceedings that take place in open court: Nicholl v Jones (1865) 2 H & M 588; 71 ER 592; Re Worswick (1888) 38 Ch D 370 ; or before an arbitrator: Rawstone v Preston Corp (1885) 30 Ch D 116 ; Goldstone v Williams, Deacon and Co [1899] 1 Ch 47 . Obviously privilege does not extend to communications that the client instructed the solicitor to repeat: Conlon v Conlons Ltd [1952] 2 All ER 462 : see Evidence Act 1995 s 122 . Neither does privilege apply to communications obtained as the result of the exercise of statutory powers to compel the disclosure of information: Trade Practices Commission v Ampol Petroleum (Vic) Pty Ltd (1994) 54 FCR 316; 127 ALR 533 .

level.toc-caption: [21.5.35] Lawyer and client — confidential communications between and documents prepared by — dominant purpose of legal proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.5.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 119.

heading.title: Lawyer and client — confidential communications between and documents prepared by — dominant purpose of legal proceedings

p.text: Client legal privilege applies to communications made with respect to litigation that is actually taking place or is reasonably apprehended: Warner v Women’s Hospital [1954] ALR 682; [1954] VLR 410 . It includes confidential communications between a lawyer, or the client, and third parties if they occurred for the dominant purpose of the client being provided with legal services relating to existing or anticipated litigation: Wheeler v Le Marchant (1881) 17 Ch D 675 ; D Byrne & J D Heydon, Cross on Evidence, Australian Edition, LexisNexis Butterworths, Sydney, 1991 to date (looseleaf), at [25210]; Evidence Act 1995 s 119 . The privilege may apply to:
drafts of pleadings and proofs of evidence: Trade Practices Commission v Ampol Petroleum (Vic) Pty Ltd (1994) 52 FCR 578; 126 ALR 111 at 115; (1994) ATPR 41–344; BC9406529 ;

communications with a litigation funder: Rickard Constructions Pty Ltd v Rickard Hails Moretti Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 234; BC200602062 ; if the agreement conveys legal advice or views about the appropriate manner of conducting the proceedings: Marshall v Prescott (No 4) [2012] NSWSC 992; BC201207114 at [72]ff — citing CSR Ltd v Eddy (2008) 70 NSWLR 725; [2008] NSWCA 83; BC200803017 .
The privilege does not apply to documents brought into existence:

as part of a particular factual investigation or routine administrative practice: Grant v Downs (1976) 135 CLR 674; 11 ALR 577; BC7600095 (hospital treatment investigation report); National Employers Mutual General Insurance Association Ltd v Waind (1979) 141 CLR 648 at 655; 24 ALR 86; BC7900050 (medical and loss assessment reports obtained by an insurer); Waugh v British Railways Board [1980] AC 521; [1979] 2 All ER 1169 (accident investigation report); Aydin v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Hodgson J, CL 15475/82, 27 August 1984, unreported) (an employer’s accident investigation reports); see also Esso Australia Resources Ltd v FCT (1999) 201 CLR 49; 168 ALR 123; [1999] HCA 67; BC9908417 at [50]; or
for the purpose of recording a solicitor client costs agreement: Cook v Pasminco Ltd (No 2) (2000) 107 FCR 44; 179 ALR 462; [2000] FCA 1819; BC200007576 or
for the purpose of commercial decision making: Waterford v The Commonwealth of Australia (1987) 163 CLR 54 at 66 and 103; 71 ALR 673; BC8701785 .

Where non-privileged documents have been submitted to expert witnesses for the purpose of obtaining their opinion, no privilege is attracted to the documents. The expert witnesses are compellable both to produce the documents and to give evidence about them: R v King [1983] 1 All ER 929; [1983] 1 WLR 411 (document submitted to handwriting expert); Harmony Shipping Co SA v Davis [1979] 3 All ER 177; [1979] 1 WLR 1380 ; MacDonald Construction Co Ltd v Lathe Plastering Co Ltd (1972) 27 DLR (3d) 253.
The question of privilege in relation to expert reports is discussed further at [31.28.40] .

level.toc-caption: [21.5.37] Third parties confidential communications with and documents prepared by — dominant purpose of legal proceedings

heading.title: Third parties confidential communications with and documents prepared by — dominant purpose of legal proceedings

p.text: Client legal privilege applies to confidential communications with third parties if they are made, by either the lawyer or the client, for the dominant purpose of existing or anticipated litigation. It also includes confidential documents (by whoever they were created) if they were prepared for the dominant purpose of a lawyer’s client being provided with legal services relating to legal proceedings. The privilege may attach to the following kinds of documents:

drafts of pleadings and proofs of evidence prepared by third parties: Nickmar Pty Ltd v Preservatrice Skandia Insurance Ltd (1985) 3 NSWLR 44; 3 ANZ Ins Cas ¶60–657 (confidential statement obtained from opposing party — privileged); Handley v Baddock [1987] WAR 98 ; compare Three Rivers District Council v Governor and Co of the Bank of England (No 5) [2003] All ER (D) 59 (Apr); [2003] QB 1556; [2003] 3 WLR 667 (documents provided to solicitors for the purpose of production at an investigative inquiry not privileged in subsequent proceedings);

expert and investigation reports commissioned by solicitors for the dominant purpose of giving advice or use in connection with reasonably anticipated litigation: Mitsubishi Electric Australia Pty Ltd v Victorian WorkCover Authority (2002) 4 VR 332; [2002] VSCA 59; BC200202330 at [16]–[19] (loss assessor's reports privileged where litigation was a real prospect);

expert report and investigation reports commissioned by, and provided to, the client for the dominant purpose of obtaining legal advice: Pratt Holdings Pty Ltd v Cmr of Taxation (2004) 207 ALR 217; 56 ATR 128; [2004] FCAFC 122; BC200402621 .
The privilege will not apply unless the document was confidential at the time it was created. Consequently, the privilege has been held not to apply to:

accident investigation reports: State of New South Wales v Jackson [2007] NSWCA 279; BC200708676 (school accident report — departmental policy requiring reports — reports asserted intended use in connection with litigation); Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v Australian Safeway Stores Pty Ltd (1998) 81 FCR 526; 153 ALR 393; BC9800786 (witness statements prepared for the dominant purpose of claim investigation not privileged notwithstanding their possible utility in foreseeable proceedings);

statements sent to a prospective witness: Newcastle Wallsend Coal Co Pty Ltd v Court of Mines Regulations (1997) 42 NSWLR 351; BC9704259 (witness provided with a copy of edited and corrected statement — no confidentiality); Drabsh v Switzerland General Insurance Co Ltd [1999] NSWSC 975; BC9906285 (witness statement): cf Fagan v State of New South Wales [2004] NSWCA 182; BC200403445 at [70] (express restriction on disclosure);
a statutory declaration provided to assist a police investigation: Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd v Marsden [1999] NSWCA 97; BC9901683 ;
a summary of legal advice provided to a regulatory authority for the purpose of the exercise of its statutory functions: Seven Network Ltd v News Ltd [2005] FCA 864; BC200504488 at [35] .
Legislation cited in [21.5.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 125.

A claim to legal privilege must sometimes give way in the face of the wider interests of the administration of justice. Thus, client legal privilege will not prevent an order being made by a court to disclose the address of a client who has control of a child of the marriage: R v Bell; Ex parte Lees (1980) 146 CLR 141; 30 ALR 489 .
