Nor can privilege be claimed in respect of a document that would tend to establish the innocence of a person charged with a criminal offence: R v Barton [1972] 2 All ER 1192; [1973] 1 WLR 115 . Further, the privilege will be denied any application to communications which are criminal in themselves or intended to facilitate the commission of a crime or conduct that renders a person liable to a civil penalty: s 125 of the Evidence Act 1995; Gartside v Outram (1856) 26 LJ Ch 113 ; R v Cox (1884) 14 QBD 153 at 165, 167; [1881–5] All ER Rep 68 ; Williams v Quebrada Railway, Land & Copper Co [1895] 2 Ch 751 at 756 ; O’Rourke v Darbishire [1920] AC 581 at 604; [1920] All ER Rep 1 ; or conduct that involves carrying out of a fraud: s 125 of the Evidence Act 1995; Varawa v Howard Smith & Co Ltd (1910) 10 CLR 382 at 386; 16 ALR 526 (the relevant purpose is that of the client, so that privilege may be lost even if the legal advisor acts innocently); Baker v Campbell (1983) 153 CLR 92; 49 ALR 385 at 409; Russell v Jackson (1851) 68 ER 558 at 560 ; Bullivant v A-G (Vic) [1901] AC 196 at 201 . Fraud in this connection is not limited to the tort of deceit but has been said to include “all forms of fraud and dishonesty such as fraudulent breach of trust, fraudulent conspiracy, trickery and sham contrivances”: Crescent Farm (Sidcup) Sports Ltd v Sterling Offıcers Ltd [1972] Ch 553 at 565 ; Attorney-General (NT) v Kearney (1985) 158 CLR 500 at 528; 61 ALR 55 ; “Legal Professional Privilege: An Engine for Fraud?” (1990) 64 ALJ 174. See also, on fraud and waiver, an article by D Hunt QC in (1992) 136 Sol Jo (UK) 430. A mere allegation of fraud is not sufficient to render the privilege inapplicable. There must be a bona fide and reasonably tenable charge of fraud or criminality and a prima facie case to show that the communication between solicitor and client was made in preparation for or furtherance of it: Australian Federal Police v Propend Finance Pty Ltd (1997) 188 CLR 501 at 553, 559, 569, 579 and 587; 141 ALR 545 ; Attorney-General (NT) v Kearney , above; O’Rourke v Darbishire, above; Butler v Board of Trade [1971] Ch 680 .

level.toc-caption: [21.5.45] Discretion to order, refuse or limit inspection

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.5.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 [21.5.50], rr 1.8, 1.9 , r 21.7, r 33.9.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 133, 183.

heading.title: Discretion to order, refuse or limit inspection

p.text: The court has a discretion whether to order the production of non-privileged documents: Kimberley Mineral Holdings Ltd (in liq) v McEwan [1980] 1 NSWLR 210; (1980) 4 ACLR 851 ; Hamilton v Naviede [1995] 2 AC 75 at 105; [1994] 3 WLR 656 ; see also r 33.9 in relation to the inspection of documents produced on subpoena. This is an aspect of the court’s incidental power to ensure that discovery and inspection are used only for relevant purposes and to protect the legitimate interests of the parties in relation to confidential information. As to the court’s ability to inspect a document for the purpose of determining an objection to disclosure, see ss 133 and 183 of the Evidence Act 1995 and also rr 1.8 and 1.9 of the UCPR. A dispute about inspection of non-privileged discovered documents may arise from various circumstances including:
the potential significance of the document in relation to the credit of a witness or party.
Legislation cited in [21.5.46] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 21.2.

The mere fact of a contractual restriction on disclosure is not usually sufficient to justify a limitation on the scope of discovery and inspection. Where the confidentiality restriction is implied (by, for example, the nature of the relationship) and probably also even when the obligation is express (see eg Howard v Odhams Press Ltd [1938] 1 KB 1 ; A v Hayden (No 2) (1985) 56 ALR 82; 59 ALJR 6; British Steel Corp v Granada Television Ltd [1981] AC 1096; [1981] 1 All ER 417 ) it is subject to recognised qualifications. Disclosure of otherwise confidential information is permissible where:
it is required by law;
the promisor is subject to a public duty or there is a public interest in disclosure (eg, matters relating to crime, fraud or public health);
the proper interests of the promisor require disclosure; or

the promisee expressly or impliedly consents to disclosure: Tournier v National Provincial and Union Bank of England [1924] 1 KB 461 at 473 per Bankes LJ; Weld-Blundell v Stephens [1919] 1 KB 520 at 527 (affirmed [1920] AC 956 at 965).

Examples of permissible disclosure under these qualifications include Initial Services Ltd v Putterill [1968] 1 QB 396; [1967] 3 All ER 145 (implied confidentiality in an employment contract does not preclude disclosure of matters involving breach of competition laws); Allied Mills Industries Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (No 1) (1981) 34 ALR 105; 55 FLR 125 (employee disclosure relating to competition legislation); Lion Laboratories Ltd v Evans [1984] 2 All ER 417; [1985] QB 526 (employee disclosure of documents questioning the accuracy of police breathalyser equipment); Malone v Metropolitan Police Cmr [1979] Ch 344 at 376–377 (tapped phone conversations — permissible use in criminal proceedings); Hubbard v Vosper [1972] 2 QB 84 (public interest disclosure of religious criticism); Church of Scientology of California v Kaufman [1973] RPC 627 at 635 . Apart from the preceding examples, disclosure of confidential information may be ordered where it is necessary to permit a party to pursue proceedings against a third party: British Steel Corp v Granada Television Ltd [1981] AC 1096; [1981] 1 All ER 417 (“newspaper rule” did not protect publisher from being required to disclose the identity of the source of “leaked” confidential documents). In each of these instances the wider public interest restricts the scope of any contractual confidentiality. But this result follows from careful identification of the scope of the public interest in the particular circumstances. Other examples illustrate that the public interest nature of the information does not, of itself, necessarily justify limiting the restraint that would otherwise apply to disclosure: Distillers Co (Biochemicals) Ltd v Times Newspapers Ltd [1975] QB 613; [1975] 1 All ER 41 (discovered documents disclosed to newspaper by expert witness — no countervailing public interest); Schering Chemicals Ltd v Faulkman Ltd [1982] QB 1 at 22; [1981] 2 All ER 321 (injunction granted to restrain disclosure of public interest information derived from confidential source despite its potential availability from public sources); Castrol Australia Pty Ltd v EmTech Assocs Pty Ltd (1980) 33 ALR 31 at 53; 51 FLR 184 (insufficient evidence of apparent statutory contravention to justify disclosure in breach of confidence). The first qualification on the restriction against disclosure of confidential information (disclosure required by law) is particularly relevant to the discovery and inspection process. Discovery is only available pursuant to an order under UCPR 21.2 . It follows that there is no automatic “compulsion” to discover “relevant” documents. In the exercise of the power to order, and define the scope of, discovery the court must consider, especially where disclosure would otherwise involve breach of a legitimate and substantial confidentiality restriction, the extent to which disclosure of the potentially relevant information is necessary for the “just, quick and cheap” disposal of the proceedings: Science Research Council v Nasse [1980] AC 1028; [1979] 3 All ER 673 . See also Imagic v Futuretronics Australia Pty Ltd (1983) 1 IPR 302 and Riker Laboratories Australia Pty Ltd v Westwood Pharmaceuticals Inc (1983) 1 IPR 343 (patent attorneys).

level.toc-caption: [21.5.47] Restricted disclosure of confidential information — protective undertakings

heading.title: Restricted disclosure of confidential information — protective undertakings

p.text: In the exercise of the power to order inspection the court may require express undertakings about the disclosure and use of the document: Church of Scientology of California v Dept of Health and Social Security [1979] 3 All ER 97 at 106–7, 113–14, 116; [1979] 1 WLR 723 at 735, 743, 746 ; Kimberley Mineral Holdings Ltd (in liq) v McEwan , above; Distillers Co (Biochemicals) Ltd v Times Newspapers Ltd [1975] QB 613 at 621; [1975] 1 All ER 41 at 48 ; Riddick v Thames Board Mills Ltd [1977] QB 881; [1977] 3 All ER 677 ; Medway v Doublelock Ltd [1978] 1 WLR 710 ; Halcon International v Shell Transport & Trading Co [1979] RPC 97 ; and see 97 LQR 377. The court may also limit the extent to which disclosure is required by restricting inspection to legal representatives or experts who have given a specific confidentiality undertaking: Warner Lambert Co v Glaxo Laboratories Ltd [1975] RPC 354 (trade secrets); Australian Broadcasting Commission v Parish (1980) 29 ALR 228; 43 FLR 129 ; Ex parte Fielder Gillespie Ltd [1984] 2 Qd R 339 ; Format Communications Manufacturing Ltd v ITT (UK) Ltd [1983] FSR 473 (inspection of computer source code).

The potential availability of restricted access orders may operate, together with the obligations imposed by CPA ss 56 and 57, to encourage parties to agree on practical arrangements to restrict disclosure of material communicated in the course of interlocutory procedures: ICAP Australia v Moebes [2010] NSWSC 738; BC201004926 at [8]–[10].

While the power to restrict disclosure, and the appropriateness of doing so in particular circumstances, are undoubted, the view has been expressed that restricting disclosure to parties’ legal representatives (and/or advisers) is generally undesirable. This is partly because of the inherent risk of inadvertent disclosure in breach of the restriction, partly because of the position of conflict in which limited disclosure places the legal representatives of the inspecting party: Commonwealth v Northern Land Council (1993) 176 CLR 604; 112 ALR 409; [1993] HCA 24; BC9303584 per Toohey J; Kanthal (Australia) Pty Ltd v Minister for Technology and Commerce (1987) 14 FCR 90, 96–97; 71 ALR 109; 12 ALD 256; Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2001] NSWSC 648; BC200104563 at [30]–[32] ; and because of the general desirability of parties being fully informed of the basis on which the proceedings are determined: Roussel Uclaf v Imperial Chemical Industries plc [1990] FSR 25 at 29–30 , ICAP Australia v Moebes [2010] NSWSC 738; BC201004926 at [11].

level.toc-caption: [21.5.48] Restricted inspection of documents material to the credit of witness or party

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.5.48] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.10.

heading.title: Restricted inspection of documents material to the credit of witness or party

p.text: The same principle that justifies restricted disclosure of confidential information can also justify non-disclosure in particular cases. For example the discretion to restrict disclosure has also been exercised to allow a defendant alleging dishonesty to withhold documents which, though not privileged, were capable of adversely affecting the plaintiff’s credibility: Markus v Provincial Insurance Co Ltd (1983) 25 NSWCCR 1; BC8300012 (insurer, who had raised an arson defence, entitled to withhold documents obtained in the course of investigating the fire); Halpin v Lumley General Insurance Ltd (2009) 258 ALR 588; [2009] NSWSC 644; BC200906618 at [31]– [41] (allegedly fraudulent insurance claim — withholding evidence of prior inconsistent statements — Markus discretion consistent with CPA provisions); see also Queensland Mines Ltd v Hudson (1976) ACLC ¶28-658 at ¶28-664; Palmer Tube Mills (Aust) Pty Ltd v Semi [1998] 4 VR 439 at 448–9; BC9800618 . Similarly, in Victoria v Davies (2003) 6 VR 245; [2003] VSCA 65; BC200302798 the Victorian Full Court held that the requirement to prepare a court tender bundle did not require a party to disclose surveillance film it intended to rely on in relation to the cross examination of the plaintiff.

In Halpin v Lumley General Insurance Ltd (2009) 261 ALR 741; [2009] NSWCA 372; BC200910469 at [89]–[94] and [97]–[101], the Court of Appeal held that restricted disclosure was not precluded by the “dictates of justice” criteria in CPA ss 57 and 58, and was within the scope of the case management powers conferred by CPA s 61. The Court of Appeal acknowledged the desirability of “caution before one party is given an apparent forensic advantage” by restricted disclosure, but it was nevertheless available “for good cause in appropriate circumstances”: [2009] NSWCA 372 at [95] and [101]; compare Boyes v Collins (2000) WAR 123 (exceptional circumstances required to justify grant of leave under UCPR r 31.10 to withhold surveillance film before trial): see [31.10.15] .

The asserted justification for limited disclosure is unlikely to apply to information about the nature of the subpoenas that a party has issued (as distinct from the documentary response to them): Prasad v AMP Life Ltd; Printer Ribbon Products Pty Ltd v AMP Life Ltd [2012] NSWSC 1076; BC201206984 . It will also have limited application if the party concerned has already disclosed the substance of the information: Forrest v NRMA Insurance [2012] ACTSC 47; BC201201762 at [19] .

level.toc-caption: [21.5.50] Discretion to order or refuse inspection — “masking” documents/redaction of material

heading.title: Discretion to order or refuse inspection — “masking” documents/redaction of material

p.text: Privilege, confidentiality and even relevance issues can arise in relation to parts of documents. It has been accepted that it is proper, if physically practicable, to withhold parts of documents where objection to inspection can be taken either on the grounds of privilege: Curlex Manufacturing v Carlingford General Insurance [1987] 2 Qd R 335 ; Grofam Pty Ltd v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (1993) 43 FCR 408; 116 ALR 535 ; Optus Communications Pty Ltd v Telstra Corp Ltd (FCA, Lockhart J, G100/93, 27 April 1995, unreported, BC9506137); or relevance: GE Capital Corporate Finance Group v Bankers Trust Co [1995] 2 All ER 993; [1995] 1 WLR 172 ; or, subject to appropriate orders, confidentiality. Often this will be done by “masking” or redacting parts of the document.

A distinction needs to be drawn according to whether the “masking” or redaction is based upon grounds of privilege or the alleged irrelevance of the contents of the document in question. In the latter case there is a serious risk that overly assiduous “masking” will detract from the comprehensibility of the remaining part of the document. Accordingly, parties should produce for inspection the whole of any discovered document unless “masking” on the ground of irrelevance is permitted by a specific provision in the order for discovery or in a subsequent order: Telstra Corp Ltd v Australis Media Holdings (NSWSC, McLelland CJ in Eq, 10 March 1997, unreported, BC9700598) and Telstra Corp Ltd v Australis Media Holdings (NSWSC, McLelland CJ in Eq, 10 February 1997, unreported, BC9700141) or by leave of the court: Drivetime Radio Australia Pty Ltd v Pivotal Creative Solutions Pty Ltd t/as Broadcast GP [2010] NSWSC 763; BC201004766 at [25] (general access to documents claimed to be irrelevant — no redaction); TZ Ltd v ZMS Investments Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 138; BC201001028 at [41] (masking of allegedly irrelevant and commercially sensitive is not, and should become, established practice); Westgate Finance Pty Ltd v May [2012] NSWSC 806; BC201205407 at [24]ff (irrelevance does not justify masking) . Where such a direction is sought the governing principle is that whilst mere irrelevance is insufficient to justify masking, the procedure of discovery should not be permitted to invade the privacy and confidentiality of the litigant’s affairs, except to the extent that the interests of justice require it in the circumstances of a particular case: Triumph International Inc v ACP Publishing Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLauglin M, 20 March 1998, unreported, BC9801406); NAK Australia Pty Ltd v Starkey Consulting Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1136; BC200809491 (masking of irrelevant pricing information permitted).

level.toc-caption: [21.5.55] Privilege — adoption of Evidence Act grounds

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.5.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

heading.title: Privilege — adoption of Evidence Act grounds

p.text: Relevant documents must be included in the discovery list even though they are subject to a justifiable privilege claim. Where privilege is claimed the list of documents must specify the basis of the claim and the affidavit served with the list must state the facts relied on to establish the privilege. The effect of the definitions of “privileged document” and “privileged information” in the Dictionary is to adopt the relevant statutory grounds of privilege and apply them to the pre-trial inspection of documents: Mok v New South Wales Crime Commission [2002] NSWCA 53; BC200200839 at [21] ; New Cap Reinsurance Corporation Ltd (in liq) v Renaissance Reinsurance Ltd [2007] NSWSC 258; BC200701984 at [15] . As a consequence, the expression “privilege” is used in the UCPR in an expanded sense which embraces most of the various statutory grounds of objection to the admission of evidence, and especially those permitted under the Evidence Act 1995 — namely:
self-incrimination privilege under ss 128 , 128A (Part 3.10 Division 2);
public interest exclusion of evidence under s 130 (Part 3.10 Division 3)
exclusion of settlement negotiations under s 131 (Part 3.10 Division 3).

In some instances these provisions of the Evidence Act 1995 permit a discretionary exclusion of evidence, rather than creating an absolute “privilege” which prevents the admission of evidence. In those instances, the rule only prevents the pre-trial inspection of the documents, subject to any contrary order of the court. In deciding whether to make a contrary order, the court must take into account the discretionary considerations that would apply under the Evidence Act 1995 to the admission of the documents into evidence. The potential relevance of those considerations may involve the court inspecting the documents: Wilson v New South Wales [2003] NSWSC 805; BC200305082 and see UCPR r 1.9 .

At common law, privilege could attach to the copies of a privileged document: Vardas v South British Insurance [1984] 2 NSWLR 652 . The same position applies under the Evidence Act 1995: Carnell v Mann (1998) 89 FCR 247 at 254; 159 ALR 647; BC9806603 . The privilege extends to include notes or extracts of the privileged documents including, for example, summaries made for the purpose of providing the legal advice to other employees or directors of the client organisation: Trade Practices Commission v Sterling (1979) 36 FLR 244 at 245–6 ; Standard Chartered Bank of Australia v Antico (1993) 36 NSWLR 87 .
Legislation cited in [21.5.65] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 cl 8 of Pt 2, ss 117–131.

At common law, the mere fact that the original of a document is privileged does not permit the claim of privilege to extend to a copy that has come into the hands of another party: Baker v Campbell (1983) 153 CLR 92; 49 ALR 385 at 394; Lloyd v Mostyn (1842) 10 M & W 478 at 482; 152 ER 558 at 560; Calcraft v Guest [1898] 1 QB 759 ; Bell v David Jones Ltd (1948) 49 SR (NSW) 223 at 227 ; Kuruma v R [1955] AC 197 at 203 ; R v Tompkins (1977) 67 Cr App R 181 at 184; Butler v Board of Trade [1971] Ch 680 at 690 ; Waugh v British Railways Board [1980] AC 521 at 536 ; Helliwell v Piggott-Sims [1980] FSR 356 . However, the application of these authorities to documents that are privileged pursuant to Evidence Act 1995 ss 117–131 is uncertain, in the light of the fact that “documents” are defined (in cl 8 of Pt 2 of the Dictionary to that Act) to include copies and extracts. Even apart from the question of privilege, in exceptional cases a copy document may not be used in evidence if it has been obtained by means that constitute a contempt of court: ITC Film Distributors Ltd v Video Exchange Ltd [1982] 1 Ch 431; R v Tompkins (1977) 67 Cr App R 181. Moreover, an action will lie to secure the return of the copied documents that have been improperly obtained by another party provided that they have not already been used in evidence: Lord Ashburton v Pape [1913] 2 Ch 469; [1911–13] All ER Rep 708 ; ITC Film Distributors Ltd v Video Exchange Ltd [1982] 1 Ch 431; Hooker Corp Ltd v Darling Harbour Authority (1987) 9 NSWLR 538 . Privilege may also extend to copies of non-privileged documents, where the copies are brought into existence for the dominant purpose of obtaining legal advice or for use in connection with legal proceedings: Commissioner of Australian Federal Police v Propend Finance Pty Ltd (1996) 188 CLR 501 at 509, 544, 554, 570; 141 ALR 545.
